articles.headline: A Financial Plan for the Truly Fed Up
articles.snippet: What to do when traditional investment choices seem riddled with deceit and incompetence? Here are some suggestions for people who want little to do with the usual road to retirement bliss.
articles.abstract: What to do when traditional investment choices seem riddled with deceit and incompetence? Here are some suggestions for people who want little to do with the usual road to retirement bliss.
articles.lead_paragraph: The deck is stacked. The game is rigged. The system is unmanageable.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Gets Encouragement From Jury That Ruled Against It
articles.snippet: The jury that acquitted a former Citigroup executive in the S.E.C.’s case against him included with the verdict a statement supporting financial investigations.
articles.abstract: The jury that acquitted a former Citigroup executive in the S.E.C.’s case against him included with the verdict a statement supporting financial investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Beau Brendler sat in the jury box listening to the government’s case against a former Citigroup midlevel executive, the same question kept entering his mind.

articles.headline: For Rebel Fight in Syrian City, Baking Bread Is Urgent Task
articles.snippet: Bread is a mainstay of the Syrian diet, eaten with every meal, and in Aleppo, paralyzed by two weeks of war, the bakery lines show that basic commerce has become a battleground.
articles.abstract: Bread is a mainstay of the Syrian diet, eaten with every meal, and in Aleppo, paralyzed by two weeks of war, the bakery lines show that basic commerce has become a battleground.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — Just before sunrise, a select group of Syrian rebel fighters steps away from the front lines here for a task their commanders now consider a vital and urgent part of the war effort: baking bread.
articles.byline: By An Employee of The New York Times in Syria and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Beach Essentials in China: Flip-Flops, a Towel and a Ski Mask
articles.snippet: In China, where pale skin is a sign of status and solar protection something of an obsession, stretchy ski masks are catching on as beachwear.
articles.abstract: In China, where pale skin is a sign of status and solar protection something of an obsession, stretchy ski masks are catching on as beachwear.
articles.lead_paragraph: QINGDAO, China — It was enough to make a trio of heavily tattooed young men stop their playful splashing and to prompt a small boy to run to his mother in alarm: a woman rising out of the choppy waves of the sea, her head wrapped in a neon-orange ski mask.

articles.headline: Trading Program Ran Amok, With No ‘Off’ Switch
articles.snippet: As a torrent of faulty trades spewed from a Knight Capital Group trading program, no one at the firm managed to stop it for more than a half-hour.
articles.abstract: As a torrent of faulty trades spewed from a Knight Capital Group trading program, no one at the firm managed to stop it for more than a half-hour.
articles.lead_paragraph: When computerized stock trading runs amok, as it did this week on Wall Street, the firm responsible typically can jump in and hit a kill switch.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Nathaniel Popper and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Bond Traders in Europe Deal in High Expectations, and Fear
articles.snippet: Traders, admittedly unsure at times, know their decisions can have an outsize effect on economic policy.
articles.abstract: Traders, admittedly unsure at times, know their decisions can have an outsize effect on economic policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — James Konrad, a bookish 27-year-old with a polite manner, used to make a living at a sports betting company, weighing the odds of muddy terrain affecting the sure-footedness of racehorses. These days, he takes bets on the muddy terrain that is European politics.

articles.headline: Two Top Afghan Security Ministers Face Dismissal
articles.snippet: Lawmakers explained a move that would cast out the heads of the army and national police in the middle of a war as part of a fight against crippling corruption and cronyism.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers explained a move that would cast out the heads of the army and national police in the middle of a war as part of a fight against crippling corruption and cronyism.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan Parliament voted Saturday to dismiss the two most powerful members of President Hamid Karzai’s security team, a surprise move that could create new turmoil as the United States-led coalition prepares to leave the country.

articles.headline: In Pursuit of Nissan, a Jobs Lesson for the Tech Industry?
articles.snippet: Executives have long said America can’t compete in building electronic devices. But the migration of carmaking from Japan is a case study in the most unlikely of transformations.
articles.abstract: Executives have long said America can’t compete in building electronic devices. But the migration of carmaking from Japan is a case study in the most unlikely of transformations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SMYRNA, Tenn. — The dairy farms that once draped the countryside here were paved over so the Japanese carmaker Nissan could build its first American assembly plant. Eighty miles to the south, another green pasture was replaced by a Nissan engine factory, and across Tennessee about 100 Nissan suppliers dot the landscape, making steel in Murfreesboro, air conditioning units in Lewisburg, transmission parts in Portland.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic, Hiroko Tabuchi and Charles Duhigg

articles.headline: Marcus Samuelsson, a Chef, a Brand and Then Some
articles.snippet: The question for Marcus Samuelsson, the chef, restaurateur, author, food impresario and media personality, is how far and how fast he can expand his personal brand.
articles.abstract: The question for Marcus Samuelsson, the chef, restaurateur, author, food impresario and media personality, is how far and how fast he can expand his personal brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARCUS SAMUELSSON, dapper in a Ralph Lauren tuxedo and patterned scarf, is working the celebrity-couture crowd at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

articles.headline: Police Protection, Please, for Municipal Bonds
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission could be more active in guarding state and local agencies against the financial firms that underwrite their bonds.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission could be more active in guarding state and local agencies against the financial firms that underwrite their bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU’VE got the power. Why not use it?

articles.headline: Record Spending by Obama’s Camp Shrinks Coffers
articles.snippet: President Obama has spent more campaign cash more quickly than any incumbent in recent history, about $400 million from the beginning of last year to June 30 this year.
articles.abstract: President Obama has spent more campaign cash more quickly than any incumbent in recent history, about $400 million from the beginning of last year to June 30 this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama has spent more campaign cash more quickly than any incumbent in recent history, betting that heavy early investments in personnel, field offices and a high-tech campaign infrastructure will propel him to victory in November.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: Leader’s Torture in the ’70s Stirs Ghosts in Brazil
articles.snippet: A Brazilian truth commission is gathering details on decades-old torture cases, including that of President Dilma Rousseff.
articles.abstract: A Brazilian truth commission is gathering details on decades-old torture cases, including that of President Dilma Rousseff.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Her nom de guerre was Estela. Part of a shadowy urban guerrilla group at the time of her capture in 1970, she spent three years behind bars, where interrogators repeatedly tortured her with electric shocks to her feet and ears, and forced her into the pau de arara, or parrot’s perch, in which victims are suspended upside down naked, from a stick, with bound wrists and ankles.

articles.headline: Fairs, Like Crops, Are Drooping With the Heat
articles.snippet: At county and state fairs across corn country this year, the most widespread drought since the 1950s is evident, as the hot summer has seeped into even the cheeriest, oldest tradition.
articles.abstract: At county and state fairs across corn country this year, the most widespread drought since the 1950s is evident, as the hot summer has seeped into even the cheeriest, oldest tradition.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEDARBURG, Wis. — The cheese curds were sizzling in vats of oil, the cartoon-colored carnival rides were spinning, and the tractors, ready to pull something heavy, were revving. Yet all was not right last week at the Ozaukee County Fair, age 153.

articles.headline: Disruptions: At Its Trial, Apple Spills Some Secrets
articles.snippet: Apple, by going to a jury trial to defend the patents of its most prized products, is allowing competitors and the public to see inside one of the most secretive companies in the world.
articles.abstract: Apple, by going to a jury trial to defend the patents of its most prized products, is allowing competitors and the public to see inside one of the most secretive companies in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Back in the early 1930s, a magician by the name of Horace Goldin went to court to defend his signature illusion: sawing a woman in half.

articles.headline: Gunman Kills 6 at a Sikh Temple Near Milwaukee
articles.snippet: In addition to the dead, three people, including a police officer, were injured in the attack at the Sikh Temple of Wisconsin, officials said.
articles.abstract: In addition to the dead, three people, including a police officer, were injured in the attack at the Sikh Temple of Wisconsin, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAK CREEK, Wis. — The priests had gathered in the lobby of the sprawling Sikh temple here in suburban Milwaukee, and lunch was being prepared as congregants were arriving for Sunday services.
articles.byline: By Steven Yaccino, Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Knight Capital Reaches Rescue Deal With Investor Group
articles.snippet: The Knight Capital Group has secured a deal on Sunday to secure a financial lifeline from an investor group that included TD Ameritrade and the Blackstone Group, capping its efforts to stay alive, a person with direct knowledge of the matter told ...
articles.abstract: The Knight Capital Group has secured a deal on Sunday to secure a financial lifeline from an investor group that included TD Ameritrade and the Blackstone Group, capping its efforts to stay alive, a person with direct knowledge of the matter told DealBook.
articles.lead_paragraph: 10:09 p.m. | Updated
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Networks Struggle to Appeal to Hispanics
articles.snippet: Shows meant to reach out to Hispanic viewers often rely on boilerplate characters that fall flat.
articles.abstract: Shows meant to reach out to Hispanic viewers often rely on boilerplate characters that fall flat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sofia Vergara is probably the most recognizable Hispanic actress working in English-language television. She is one of the stars of “Modern Family,” among the highest-rated scripted shows on network television, and she has parlayed her celebrity into commercials for brands like Pepsi and Cover Girl.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Aggregators Help Radio Reach Online Audiences
articles.snippet: Two apps, iHeart Radio, from Clear Channel Communications, and TuneIn, help broadcasters reach new listeners. There are concerns, though, about the cost of online royalties and the two companies’ plans.
articles.abstract: Two apps, iHeart Radio, from Clear Channel Communications, and TuneIn, help broadcasters reach new listeners. There are concerns, though, about the cost of online royalties and the two companies’ plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the radio industry, there may be no better symbol for the challenges of adapting to the digital age than two candy-colored mobile apps.

articles.headline: Security Start-Ups Catch Fancy of Investors
articles.snippet: In the last year, the initial public offerings of once obscure security start-ups have outperformed the offerings from household names like Facebook and Zynga.
articles.abstract: In the last year, the initial public offerings of once obscure security start-ups have outperformed the offerings from household names like Facebook and Zynga.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — The question is no longer who have hackers hit. It is who has not been hit.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Evelyn M. Rusli

articles.headline: Zillow and Other Sites Broaden Their Mission to Include Businesses
articles.snippet: Zillow, an online real estate information service, is among an increasing number of Internet companies trying to cater to businesses as well as consumers.
articles.abstract: Zillow, an online real estate information service, is among an increasing number of Internet companies trying to cater to businesses as well as consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For the first few years of its existence, the only thing Zillow cared about was getting people to come to its real estate Web site to snoop on the market value of neighbors’ homes and other properties. Over 34 million visitors a month now do so.

articles.headline: Fearing an Impasse in Congress, Industry Cuts Spending
articles.snippet: Executives at a wide range of companies fear paralysis in Washington will force hundreds of billions in tax increases and budget cuts in January, leading them to cancel new investments and put off new hires.
articles.abstract: Executives at a wide range of companies fear paralysis in Washington will force hundreds of billions in tax increases and budget cuts in January, leading them to cancel new investments and put off new hires.
articles.lead_paragraph: A rising number of manufacturers are canceling new investments and putting off new hires because they fear paralysis in Washington will force hundreds of billions in tax increases and budget cuts in January, undermining economic growth in the coming months.

articles.headline: As Libor Fault-Finding Grows, It Is Now Every Bank for Itself
articles.snippet: Sources said the investigation into suspected manipulation of the Libor benchmark has led banks to cooperate by sharing information that they say implicates their rivals.
articles.abstract: Sources said the investigation into suspected manipulation of the Libor benchmark has led banks to cooperate by sharing information that they say implicates their rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major banks, which often band together when facing government scrutiny, are now turning on one another as an international investigation into the manipulation of interest rates gains momentum.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Outside Cash in Missouri Race Could Be a National Model
articles.snippet: The campaign against Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri, fueled by tax-exempt groups backing Republican candidates, may be a precursor to such efforts on a broader scale.
articles.abstract: The campaign against Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri, fueled by tax-exempt groups backing Republican candidates, may be a precursor to such efforts on a broader scale.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Missouri’s long, divisive Republican Senate primary draws to a close Tuesday, but after all the intraparty fireworks, it is the incumbent Democrat, Senator Claire McCaskill, who remains in deep trouble.

articles.headline: Saying Mali ‘Is Our Country,’ Militias Train to Oust Islamists
articles.snippet: Fledgling citizen militias have taken on the task of standing up to an array of Islamist fighters bent on enforcing a hard-edged brand of Shariah law in Mali.
articles.abstract: Fledgling citizen militias have taken on the task of standing up to an array of Islamist fighters bent on enforcing a hard-edged brand of Shariah law in Mali.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOPTI, Mali — Hundreds of young men are stuffed into makeshift training camps near this provincial capital, arising at 4 a.m. for physical exercises and simulated hand-to-hand combat in preparation for the day when they can free their north Mali homeland from the radical Islamists whose harsh rule has driven tens of thousands of frightened, desperate civilians to flee the country.

articles.headline: Prime Minister’s Defection in the Dark Jolts Syrians
articles.snippet: The defection of Syria’s prime minister, Riyad Farid Hijab, planned furtively for weeks, spurred jubilation in the opposition but seemed unlikely to end the war.
articles.abstract: The defection of Syria’s prime minister, Riyad Farid Hijab, planned furtively for weeks, spurred jubilation in the opposition but seemed unlikely to end the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The defection of Syria’s prime minister, Riyad Farid Hijab, began like so many others: with coded conversations and furtive planning. He began discussing the idea of fleeing, an aide said, as soon as President Bashar al-Assad strong-armed him into taking the job in June. In recent days, he worked to get his extended family out. Then, early Monday, the prime minister slipped out of Damascus under cover of darkness with his wife and four children, scrambling through the desert as a fugitive.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Dalal Mawad

articles.headline: Wisconsin Killer Fed and Was Fueled by Hate-Driven Music
articles.snippet: Wade M. Page, who the authorities said killed six people at a Sikh temple, was a white supremacist who performed in a racist rock band.
articles.abstract: Wade M. Page, who the authorities said killed six people at a Sikh temple, was a white supremacist who performed in a racist rock band.
articles.lead_paragraph: His music, Wade M. Page once said, was about “how the value of human life has been degraded by tyranny.”
articles.byline: By Erica Goode and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: Regulator Says British Bank Helped Iran Hide Deals
articles.snippet: Standard Chartered, motivated by the millions of dollars it reaped in fees, schemed with the Iranian government to launder $250 billion, New York’s banking regulator said.
articles.abstract: Standard Chartered, motivated by the millions of dollars it reaped in fees, schemed with the Iranian government to launder $250 billion, New York’s banking regulator said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Using its New York-based operations, a major British bank schemed with the Iranian government for nearly a decade to launder $250 billion, leaving the United States financial system vulnerable to terrorists and corrupt regimes, New York’s top banking regulator charged on Monday.
